title: P05-2013

sentences.text: This paper presents the results of automatically inducing a Combinatory Categorial Grammar -LRB- CCG -RRB- lexicon from a Turkish dependency treebank .
The fact that Turkish is an agglutinating free word order language presents a challenge for language theories .
We explored possible ways to obtain a compact lexicon , consistent with CCG principles , from a treebank which is an order of magnitude smaller than Penn WSJ .

Entity-ccg_principle.label: CCG principles
Entity-ccg_principle.description: Principles governing Combinatory Categorial Grammar (CCG) theory, guiding the construction and organization of a lexicon.

Entity-combinatory_categorial_grammar.label: Combinatory Categorial Grammar
Entity-combinatory_categorial_grammar.description: A linguistic theory that combines categorial grammar with combinatorial principles to analyze sentence structure and meaning.

Entity-treebank.description: A collection of annotated linguistic examples or texts used to train and evaluate natural language processing models.

Entity-turkish.description: A language spoken in Turkey and other countries, characterized by its unique grammar and vocabulary.

Entity-ccg.label: CCG
Entity-ccg.description: A linguistic framework or theory that describes the compositional semantics and syntax of natural language.

Entity-lexicon.label: lexicon
Entity-lexicon.description: A collection of words and their meanings, often organized in a systematic way.

Entity-penn_wsj.label: Penn WSJ
Entity-penn_wsj.description: A widely used corpus and dataset for natural language processing research

Entity-language_theory.label: language theories
Entity-language_theory.description: A set of conceptual frameworks or models used to explain and analyze linguistic phenomena, including syntax, semantics, pragmatics, and phonology.

Entity-fact.label: fact
Entity-fact.description: A piece of information or observation, often resulting from investigation or research.

summary: This paper presents the results of automatically inducing a Combinatory Categorial Grammar -LRB- CCG -RRB- lexicon from a Turkish dependency treebank . The fact that Turkish is an agglutinating free word order language presents a challenge for language theories . We explored possible ways to obtain a compact lexicon , consistent with CCG principles , from a treebank which is an order of magnitude smaller than Penn WSJ .

Predicate-induces.label: induces
Predicate-induces.description: Induces a relationship or pattern between two entities, often implying causality or influence. The subject of this predicate represents an entity that brings about or causes something to happen in the object.

Predicate-presents.label: presents
Predicate-presents.description: To present means to offer or display something, typically in a formal setting. In this sense, the predicate 'presents' indicates that the subject (typically an entity responsible for providing information) provides access to or reveals the object, which can be ideas, findings, results, or other types of knowledge.

Predicate-explored.label: explored
Predicate-explored.description: To explore means to investigate or examine something thoroughly, often with the intention of gaining insight, understanding, or knowledge. The subject performs an act of investigation, analysis, or discovery on the object, seeking to uncover its properties, characteristics, or potential.

Predicate-are_consistent_with.label: are consistent with
Predicate-are_consistent_with.description: The predicate 'are consistent with' indicates that there exists a relationship between two entities where one entity (the subject) exhibits properties or characteristics that align with, match, or conform to those of another entity (the object). This connection suggests similarity, harmony, or coherence between the subject and object.

skos:broader.label: has a broader term
skos:broader.description: The predicate 'has a broader term' indicates that the subject concept is a specific instance or member of a more general category or class denoted by the object. In other words, it establishes an is-a relationship between the two concepts.
